content.raw: Yep, this is a trivial process for us. Just let us know of any new robots/configs so that we can add them to the whitelist. Thanks Addisu!
content.html: Yep, this is a trivial process for us. Just let us know of any new robots/configs so that we can add them to the whitelist. Thanks Addisu!

update.description:
This PR adds support using vehicles contributed by external organizations. I propose that model submissions consist of a single ROS package that contains the following:

* An ignition-gazebo SDF model
* A URDF file derived from the ignition-gazebo SDF model
* Resources \(meshes, materials, etc\) needed and shared by the ignition-gazebo SDF model and the URDF
* A `spawner.rb` file that contains a `spawn` function that returns the SDF string for spawning the model into ignition-gazebo. This file is to be included by the main SubT launch files to spawn the model. It is assumed that this file will reside in `<package>/launch/`
* `vehicle_topics.launch` which launches the ROS-IGN bridge needed by the model. This launch file is to be used by `spawner.rb`
* `description.launch` which sets the robot\_description parameter of the robot from the URDF file. This launch file is also to be used by `spawner.rb`

Here's an example directory structure:

```
submitted_models
└── husky_migration_sensor_config_1
    ├── CMakeLists.txt
    ├── launch
    │   ├── description.launch
    │   ├── example.ign
    │   ├── spawner.rb
    │   └── vehicle_topics.launch
    ├── meshes
    │   ├── base_link.dae
    │   ├── bumper.dae
    │   ├── lms1xx_mount.dae
    │   ├── meshes.txt
    │   ├── sick-lms1xx.dae
    │   ├── top_chassis.dae
    │   ├── top_plate.dae
    │   ├── user_rail.dae
    │   └── wheel.dae
    ├── model.config
    ├── model.sdf
    ├── package.xml
    ├── thumbnails
    │   ├── 1.png
    │   ├── 2.png
    │   ├── 3.png
    │   ├── 4.png
    │   └── 5.png
    ├── urdf
    │   ├── husky_migration.orig.urdf
    │   └── robot_from_sdf.xacro
    └── worlds
        └── example.sdf

6 directories, 25 files
```

A team submission will be in the form of a PR that adds a new directory to `submitted_models`. To launch a robot submitted by a team, the ROS package name is passed to `robotConfigX` parameter of the SubT launch files.

For example, the [team\_submission\_example](#!/osrf/subt/src/team_submission_example/submitted_models/husky_migration_sensor_config_1/) contains an example package called `husky_migration_sensor_config_1`. To test this robot, checkout that branch \(i.e. `hg checkout team_submission_example`\) and run

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=alpha robotConfig1:=husky_migration_sensor_config_1 localModel:=true 
```

To be consistent with `robotConfigX` parameters of `X1`- `X4`, an all upper case value can be used \(e.g., `robotConfig1:=HUSKY_MIGRATION_SENSOR_CONFIG_1`\).

The `localModel` parameter is added to facilitate testing during the PR review process. Once the PR is merged, the Gazebo relevant files will be uploaded to Fuel. When uploading to Fuel, the ROS package name must be used as the name of the model on Fuel. This implies following the ROS package naming conventions \(i.e, no spaces, use underscores, use lowercase letters\).

Organizations will be encouraged to name their submission with the pattern `<organization_name>_<robot_name>_sensor_config_<#>` and the corresponding command line variable name `<ORGANIZATION_NAME>_<ROBOT_NAME>_SENSOR_CONFIG_<#>`

The [SubT API Wiki](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api) should be used as a reference for topic naming and other conventions.

Organizations can refer to the [Model Submission Process Guide](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/Model%20Submission%20Process) for a step by step instructions on creating a model submission PR.

**Requirements**

* ign-launch >= 1.3.0
* ign-gazebo >= 2.11
* libsdformat >= 8.4

‌
update.title: Support model submissions

content.raw: Thanks for the review @{557058:d30370f4-284a-4762-a32f-25b280051754}. I would be okay with a workflow where adding the model to the whitelist is part of the PR review and approval process. Is adding an item to the whitelist easy to do for you?
content.html: Thanks for the review @Alejo Carballude. I would be okay with a workflow where adding the model to the whitelist is part of the PR review and approval process. Is adding an item to the whitelist easy to do for you?

content.raw:
This looks great! I did not know this feature was underway. 

When teams request simulations on Cloudsim, it currently validates that the robot configurations sent are inside a whitelist. If a user sends a robot config that’s not in the whitelist, the simulation is rejected. If I understand correctly, these team-submitted models/configs will be stored within the `subt_sim:cloudsim_sim_latest` image.

Cloudsim needs to have the list of available robots upfront to be able to create the whitelist. We don’t really have access to the contents of the simulation image from within Cloudsim as this image is only pulled when launching simulations. Consequently, this will require that the Cloudsim team is notified of any team-submitted config that is approved, in order to add it to the whitelist.

I’m open to changing to a validation scheme that is not as cumbersome, but I don’t have any specific ideas right now. When setting up the validation at the time, we did not expect the number of configs to change too much so a whitelist system was good enough.
content.html:
This looks great! I did not know this feature was underway.

When teams request simulations on Cloudsim, it currently validates that the robot configurations sent are inside a whitelist. If a user sends a robot config that’s not in the whitelist, the simulation is rejected. If I understand correctly, these team-submitted models/configs will be stored within the subt_sim:cloudsim_sim_latest image.

Cloudsim needs to have the list of available robots upfront to be able to create the whitelist. We don’t really have access to the contents of the simulation image from within Cloudsim as this image is only pulled when launching simulations. Consequently, this will require that the Cloudsim team is notified of any team-submitted config that is approved, in order to add it to the whitelist.

I’m open to changing to a validation scheme that is not as cumbersome, but I don’t have any specific ideas right now. When setting up the validation at the time, we did not expect the number of configs to change too much so a whitelist system was good enough.

content.raw: Excellent, but can you do Urban instead Tunnel?  Kidding!  Thanks AJ!
content.html: Excellent, but can you do Urban instead Tunnel? Kidding! Thanks AJ!

content.raw: Great, thanks AJ.  Would you mind attaching a screenshot showing the spawned vehicle inside world?
content.html: Great, thanks AJ. Would you mind attaching a screenshot showing the spawned vehicle inside world?

This PR adds support using vehicles contributed by external organizations. I propose that model submissions consist of a single ROS package that contains the following:

* An ignition-gazebo SDF model
* A URDF file derived from the ignition-gazebo SDF model
* Resources \(meshes, materials, etc\) needed and shared by the ignition-gazebo SDF model and the URDF
* A `spawner.rb` file that contains a `spawn` function that returns the SDF string for spawning the model into ignition-gazebo. This file is to be included by the main SubT launch files to spawn the model. It is assumed that this file will reside in `<package>/launch/`
* `vehicle_topics.launch` which launches the ROS-IGN bridge needed by the model. This launch file is to be used by `spawner.rb`
* `description.launch` which sets the robot\_description parameter of the robot from the URDF file. This launch file is also to be used by `spawner.rb`

Here's an example directory structure:

```
submitted_models
└── husky_migration_sensor_config_1
    ├── CMakeLists.txt
    ├── launch
    │   ├── description.launch
    │   ├── example.ign
    │   ├── spawner.rb
    │   └── vehicle_topics.launch
    ├── meshes
    │   ├── base_link.dae
    │   ├── bumper.dae
    │   ├── lms1xx_mount.dae
    │   ├── meshes.txt
    │   ├── sick-lms1xx.dae
    │   ├── top_chassis.dae
    │   ├── top_plate.dae
    │   ├── user_rail.dae
    │   └── wheel.dae
    ├── model.config
    ├── model.sdf
    ├── package.xml
    ├── thumbnails
    │   ├── 1.png
    │   ├── 2.png
    │   ├── 3.png
    │   ├── 4.png
    │   └── 5.png
    ├── urdf
    │   ├── husky_migration.orig.urdf
    │   └── robot_from_sdf.xacro
    └── worlds
        └── example.sdf

6 directories, 25 files
```

A team submission will be in the form of a PR that adds a new directory to `submitted_models`. To launch a robot submitted by a team, the ROS package name is passed to `robotConfigX` parameter of the SubT launch files.

For example, the [team\_submission\_example](#!/osrf/subt/src/team_submission_example/submitted_models/husky_migration_sensor_config_1/) contains an example package called `husky_migration_sensor_config_1`. To test this robot, checkout that branch \(i.e. `hg checkout team_submission_example`\) and run

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=alpha robotConfig1:=husky_migration_sensor_config_1 localModel:=true 
```

To be consistent with `robotConfigX` parameters of `X1`- `X4`, an all upper case value can be used \(e.g., `robotConfig1:=HUSKY_MIGRATION_SENSOR_CONFIG_1`\).

The `localModel` parameter is added to facilitate testing during the PR review process. Once the PR is merged, the Gazebo relevant files will be uploaded to Fuel. When uploading to Fuel, the ROS package name must be used as the name of the model on Fuel. This implies following the ROS package naming conventions \(i.e, no spaces, use underscores, use lowercase letters\).

Organizations will be encouraged to name their submission with the pattern `<organization_name>_<robot_name>_sensor_config_<#>` and the corresponding command line variable name `<ORGANIZATION_NAME>_<ROBOT_NAME>_SENSOR_CONFIG_<#>`

The [SubT API Wiki](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/api) should be used as a reference for topic naming and other conventions.

Organizations can refer to the [Model Submission Process Guide](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/Model%20Submission%20Process) for a step by step instructions on creating a model submission PR.

**Requirements**

* ign-launch >= 1.3.0
* ign-gazebo >= 2.11
* libsdformat >= 8.4

* An ignition-gazebo SDF model
* A URDF file derived from the ignition-gazebo SDF model
* Resources \(meshes, materials, etc\) needed and shared by the ignition-gazebo SDF model and the URDF
* A `spawner.rb` file that contains a `spawn` function that returns the SDF string for spawning the model into ignition-gazebo. This file is to be included by the main SubT launch files to spawn the model. It is assumed that this file will reside in `<package>/launch/`
* `vehicle_topics.launch` which launches the ROS-IGN bridge needed by the model. This launch file is to be used by `spawner.rb`
* `description.launch` which sets the robot\_description parameter of the robot from the URDF file. This launch file is also to be used by `spawner.rb`

Here's an example directory structure:

```
submitted_models
└── husky_migration_sensor_config_1
    ├── CMakeLists.txt
    ├── launch
    │   ├── description.launch
    │   ├── example.ign
    │   ├── spawner.rb
    │   └── vehicle_topics.launch
    ├── meshes
    │   ├── base_link.dae
    │   ├── bumper.dae
    │   ├── lms1xx_mount.dae
    │   ├── meshes.txt
    │   ├── sick-lms1xx.dae
    │   ├── top_chassis.dae
    │   ├── top_plate.dae
    │   ├── user_rail.dae
    │   └── wheel.dae
    ├── model.config
    ├── model.sdf
    ├── package.xml
    ├── thumbnails
    │   ├── 1.png
    │   ├── 2.png
    │   ├── 3.png
    │   ├── 4.png
    │   └── 5.png
    ├── urdf
    │   ├── husky_migration.orig.urdf
    │   └── robot_from_sdf.xacro
    └── worlds
        └── example.sdf

6 directories, 25 files
```

A team submission will be in the form of a PR that adds a new directory to `submitted_models`. To launch a robot submitted by a team, the ROS package name is passed to `robotConfigX` parameter of the SubT launch files.

For example, the [team\_submission\_example](#!/osrf/subt/src/team_submission_example/submitted_models/husky_migration_sensor_config_1/) contains an example package called `husky_migration_sensor_config_1`. To test this robot, checkout that branch and run

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=alpha robotConfig1:=husky_migration_sensor_config_1 localModel:=true 
```

To be consistent with `robotConfigX` parameters of `X1`- `X4`, an all upper case value can be used \(e.g., `robotConfig1:=HUSKY_MIGRATION_SENSOR_CONFIG_1`\). 

The `localModel` parameter is added to facilitate testing during the PR review process. Once the PR is merged, the Gazebo relevant files will be uploaded to Fuel. When uploading to Fuel, the ROS package name must be used as the name of the model on Fuel. This implies following the ROS package naming conventions \(i.e, no spaces, use underscores, use lowercase letters\). 

Teams will be encouraged to name their submission with the pattern `<organization_name>_<robot_name>_sensor_config_<#>` and the corresponding command line variable name `<ORGANIZATION_NAME>_<ROBOT_NAME>_SENSOR_CONFIG_<#>`

**Requirements**

* ign-launch >= 1.3.0
* ign-gazebo >= 2.11
* libsdformat >= 8.4

‌
update.title: Support model submissions

content.raw: Great! I have made all the changes except adding a link to the Model Submission Process wiki. Let me know if I missed anything.
content.html: Great! I have made all the changes except adding a link to the Model Submission Process wiki. Let me know if I missed anything.

update.description:
This PR adds support using vehicles contributed by teams. I propose that team submissions consist of a single ROS package that contains the following:

* An ignition-gazebo SDF model
* A URDF file derived from the ignition-gazebo SDF model
* Resources \(meshes, materials, etc\) needed and shared by the ignition-gazebo SDF model and the URDF
* A `spawner.rb` file that contains a `spawn` function that returns the SDF string for spawning the model into ignition-gazebo. This file is to be included by the main SubT launch files to spawn the model. It is assumed that this file will reside in `<package>/launch/`
* `vehicle_topics.launch` which launches the ROS-IGN bridge needed by the model. This launch file is to be used by `spawner.rb`
* `description.launch` which sets the robot\_description parameter of the robot from the URDF file. This launch file is also to be used by `spawner.rb`
    

Here's an example directory structure:

```
submitted_models
└── husky_migration_sensor_config_1
    ├── CMakeLists.txt
    ├── launch
    │   ├── description.launch
    │   ├── example.ign
    │   ├── spawner.rb
    │   └── vehicle_topics.launch
    ├── meshes
    │   ├── base_link.dae
    │   ├── bumper.dae

    │   ├── meshes.txt
    │   ├── sick-lms1xx.dae
    │   ├── top_chassis.dae
    │   ├── top_plate.dae
    │   ├── user_rail.dae
    │   └── wheel.dae
    ├── model.config
    ├── model.sdf
    ├── package.xml
    ├── thumbnails
    │   ├── 1.png
    │   ├── 2.png
    │   ├── 3.png
    │   ├── 4.png
    │   └── 5.png
    ├── urdf
    │   ├── husky_migration.orig.urdf
    │   └── robot_from_sdf.xacro
    └── worlds
        └── example.sdf

6 directories, 25 files


```

A team submission will be in the form of a PR that adds a new directory to `subt_team_submissions`. To launch a robot submitted by a team, the ROS package name is passed to `robotConfigX` parameter of the SubT launch files.

For example, the [team\_submission\_example](#!/osrf/subt/src/team_submission_example/submitted_models/husky_migration_sensor_config_1/) contains an example package called `husky_migration_sensor_config_1`. To test this robot, checkout that branch and run

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=R robotConfig1:=husky_migration_sensor_config_1 localModel:=true 
```

The `localModel` parameter is added to facilitate testing during the PR review process. Once the PR is merged, the Gazebo relevant files will be uploaded to Fuel. When uploading to Fuel, the ROS package name must be used as the name of the model on Fuel. This implies following the ROS package naming conventions \(i.e, no spaces, use underscores, use lowercase letters\).

To be consistent with `robotConfigX` parameters of `X1`- `X4`, an all upper case value can be used

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=R robotConfig1:=HUSKY_MIGRATION_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 localModel:=true 
```

Teams will be encouraged to name their submission with the pattern`<organization name>_<robot_name>_sensor_config_<#>` and the corresponding command line variable name `<ORGANIZATION_NAME>_<ROBOT_NAME>_SENSOR_CONFIG_<#>`

**Requirements**

* ign-launch >= 1.3.0
* ign-gazebo >= 2.11
* libsdformat >= 8.4

‌
update.title: Support team submissions

content.raw:
My mistake, since the model has sensors, please make it `HUSKY_MIGRATION_SENSOR_CONFIG_1`.  
My intent with removing `_sensor_` was to reduce package name lengths, but it isn’t a huge difference so you can go ahead and make the package name `husky_migration_sensor_config_1` as well.
content.html:
My mistake, since the model has sensors, please make it HUSKY_MIGRATION_SENSOR_CONFIG_1.
My intent with removing _sensor_ was to reduce package name lengths, but it isn’t a huge difference so you can go ahead and make the package name husky_migration_sensor_config_1 as well.

content.raw: I'm working on making your recommended changes. Quick question: You suggested that the ROS package name be updated to `husky_migration_config_0` without `_sensor_`, but the model does have an IMU and a lidar. Also, the launch variable contains `_SENSOR_`. I was hoping to keep the launch variable and the package name the same except capitalization. Is it okay to update it to `husky_migration_sensor_config_0`?
content.html: I'm working on making your recommended changes. Quick question: You suggested that the ROS package name be updated to husky_migration_config_0 without _sensor_, but the model does have an IMU and a lidar. Also, the launch variable contains _SENSOR_. I was hoping to keep the launch variable and the package name the same except capitalization. Is it okay to update it to husky_migration_sensor_config_0?

content.raw:
I like the explicit callout of a local model in the launch command, to be clear where your model is being loaded from. Appreciate the directory structure and example PR as well.  
Recommended changes:

* Change directory `subt_team_submissions` to `submitted_models` since non-competing organizations can submit models
* Naming convention should more closely follow naming for X1-X4:  “Teams will be encouraged to name their submission with the ROS package name `<organization_name>_<robot_name>_config_<#>` and variable name `<ORGANIZATION_NAME>_<ROBOT_NAME>_SENSOR_CONFIG_<#>`“

    * Update this ROS package name to `husky_migration_config_0` \(since there are no sensors in this model\)
    * Update launch variable \(all-caps version only\)  to `HUSKY_MIGRATION_SENSOR_CONFIG_0`  resulting in “`ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=HUSKY robotConfig1:=HUSKY_MIGRATION_SENSOR_CONFIG_0 localModel:=true`”
    
* Change "team\_submission\_example" link to the following so the directory is immediately visible: [#!/osrf/subt/src/team\_submission\_example/subt\_team\_submissions/husky\_migration/](https://slack-redir.net/link?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbitbucket.org%2Fosrf%2Fsubt%2Fsrc%2Fteam_submission_example%2Fsubt_team_submissions%2Fhusky_migration%2F)
* Add a link to the Model Submission Process \(AJ’s wiki\) when available
* \[Formatting\] Reduce bullet level for `vehicle_topics.launch` and `description.launch` items to be inline with previous bullets

‌
content.html:
I like the explicit callout of a local model in the launch command, to be clear where your model is being loaded from. Appreciate the directory structure and example PR as well.
Recommended changes:

  • Change directory subt_team_submissions to submitted_models since non-competing organizations can submit models

  • Naming convention should more closely follow naming for X1-X4: “Teams will be encouraged to name their submission with the ROS package name <organization_name>_<robot_name>_config_<#> and variable name <ORGANIZATION_NAME>_<ROBOT_NAME>_SENSOR_CONFIG_<#>“

    • Update this ROS package name to husky_migration_config_0 (since there are no sensors in this model)
    • Update launch variable (all-caps version only) to HUSKY_MIGRATION_SENSOR_CONFIG_0 resulting in “ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=HUSKY robotConfig1:=HUSKY_MIGRATION_SENSOR_CONFIG_0 localModel:=true”

  • Change "team_submission_example" link to the following so the directory is immediately visible: #!/osrf/subt/src/team_submission_example/subt_team_submissions/husky_migration/

  • Add a link to the Model Submission Process (AJ’s wiki) when available
  • [Formatting] Reduce bullet level for vehicle_topics.launch and description.launch items to be inline with previous bullets

‌

update.description:
This PR adds support using vehicles contributed by teams. I propose that team submissions consist of a single ROS package that contains the following:

* An ignition-gazebo SDF model
* A URDF file derived from the ignition-gazebo SDF model
* Resources \(meshes, materials, etc\) needed and shared by the ignition-gazebo SDF model and the URDF
* A `spawner.rb` file that contains a `spawn` function that returns the SDF string for spawning the model into ignition-gazebo. This file is to be included by the main SubT launch files to spawn the model. It is assumed that this file will reside in `<package>/launch/`

    * `vehicle_topics.launch` which launches the ROS-IGN bridge needed by the model. This launch file is to be used by `spawner.rb`
    * `description.launch` which sets the robot\_description parameter of the robot from the URDF file. This launch file is also to be used by `spawner.rb`
    

Here's an example directory structure:

```
subt_team_submissions/husky_migration
├── CMakeLists.txt
├── launch
│   ├── description.launch
│   ├── example.ign
│   ├── spawner.rb
│   └── vehicle_topics.launch
├── materials
│   └── textures
├── meshes
│   ├── base_link.dae
│   ├── bumper.dae
│   ├── lms1xx_mount.dae
│   ├── meshes.txt
│   ├── sick-lms1xx.dae
│   ├── top_chassis.dae
│   ├── top_plate.dae
│   ├── user_rail.dae
│   └── wheel.dae
├── model.config
├── model.sdf
├── package.xml
├── urdf
│   ├── husky_migration.orig.urdf
│   └── robot_from_sdf.xacro
└── worlds
    └── example.sdf

6 directories, 20 files
```

A team submission will be in the form of a PR that adds a new directory to `subt_team_submissions`. To launch a robot submitted by a team, the ROS package name is passed to `robotConfigX` parameter of the SubT launch files.

For example, the [team\_submission\_example](#!/osrf/subt/branch/team_submission_example) contains an example package called `husky_migration`. To test this robot, checkout that branch and run

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=R robotConfig1:=husky_migration localModel:=true 
```

The `localModel` parameter is added to facilitate testing during the PR review process. Once the PR is merged, the Gazebo relevant files will be uploaded to Fuel. When uploading to Fuel, the ROS package name must be used as the name of the model on Fuel. This implies following the ROS package naming conventions \(i.e, no spaces, use underscores, use lowercase letters\).

To be consistent with `robotConfigX` parameters of `X1`- `X4`, an all upper case value can be used

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=HUSKY_MIGRATION localModel:=true 
```

Teams will be encouraged to name their submission with the pattern`<team name>_<robot_name>_sensor_config_<config number>`

**Requirements**

* ign-launch >= 1.3.0
* ign-gazebo >= 2.11
* libsdformat >= 8.4

‌
